Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Implications of Coronavirus for Prejudices, Cultural Change, and Health

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: The threat of infectious disease changes how people think and act in a number of ways. Some of these changes are obvious, such as hoarding and increased anxiety. Other changes are less obvious, such as increased negative feelings toward groups associated with disease and greater aversion to novelty. Both types of changes have significant implications for societal well-being and health. Infectious disease was once the leading source of mortality for humans. As a result, humans evolved a number of behavioral and cultural responses to help avoid infection. The spread of coronavirus provides a unique opportunity to explore important theoretical questions to better understand the psychological processes relating to perceptions of disease. This project investigates how disease cues are perceived and how they influence behavior in the context of a real-world threat (COVID-19). The research tests how local disease rates and other contextual factors influence the perceptions of disease cues and how this is influenced by various forms of bias. The research also tests the extent to which the spread of the coronavirus shapes the health-related behaviors and cognition of groups who are stigmatically associated with infectious disease. Because of the associated stigma of disease, it is hypothesized that some groups will avoid seeking treatment and will mask their disease symptoms, further exacerbating a dire situation. Phenomena cued by infectious disease threat (such as prejudice, stigma, or policy preferences) can have important consequences for efforts to reduce and treat infectious disease during epidemics. Refining such models will inform public health responses regarding the current outbreak and policies pertaining to future outbreaks. The COVID-19 pandemic will have broad economic and social impacts. Governments, institutions, and corporations will benefit from further understanding and modeling as they seek to respond and adapt to this crisis and future crises.<br/><br/>This RAPID project employs a mixed-methods approach (using big data and archival time-series data analyses, large-scale longitudinal surveys, and a cross-national study) to answer key questions regarding the social dynamics of how humans respond to infectious disease threat. By studying the spread of coronavirus in concert with changes in prejudices, social attitudes, and other social variables, the research tests the hypothesis that the behavioral immune system produces specific threat perceptions, cultural ideologies, behaviors, and practices associated with disease avoidance and other adaptive responses to infectious disease threat. The research assesses the extent to which prejudiced and discriminatory reactions to a variety of targets (ethnic minorities, sexual minorities, the obese, the elderly, immigrants) are specific to disease-related targets or are generalized to all outgroups. It also assesses the experiences and health-relevant decision making of groups who are sometimes stigmatized by their association with infectious diseases, lending insight into how stigma and prejudice influence health-related behaviors. The project aims to create new theoretical bridges among a diverse range of disciplines including social psychology, evolutionary psychology, epidemiology, public health, and econometrics.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Infectious diseases pose critically dangerous threats. As a consequence, humans have evolved an immune system designed to neutralize pathogens once they make it into the body. However, battling infection is very costly metabolically, and the potential of serious illness and death are significant. For this reason, humans have also evolved a ?behavioral immune system? designed to avoid infection in the first place. This system includes components such as aversion to novelty, the emotion of disgust, inclinations toward behavioral avoidance, and prejudices toward specific groups that heuristically cue disease. A second pathogen-defense system has been the cultural evolution of social practices and ideologies (e.g., conformity, preference for tradition) that mitigate against the acquisition and spread of infectious pathogens.

The coronavirus pandemic provides a unique opportunity to explore important theoretical questions in the understanding of nuanced psychological and social mechanisms tied to the presence of high disease loads and their perception. By studying the ongoing temporal dynamics of coronavirus spread, prejudices, political preferences, etc., and their relationships to one another, one can answer important questions about the behavioral immune system and disease-defending cultural ideologies and practices. 

This research employed a mixed-method approach, in which well-curated longitudinal data mined from existing archival sources were complemented with the design of new, highly-focused longitudinal surveys and experiments on threat detection. The research primarily aimed to better understand (1) the extent to which, and the ways in which, prejudiced and discriminatory reactions to a variety of groups (i.e., ethnic minorities, political partisans, sexual minorities, the obese, the elderly, immigrants) might be shaped by perceptions of infectious disease transmission over the course of the COVID pandemic, and the factors that influence those effects; and (2) the experiences and health-relevant decision making of groups who are stigmatized because they are stereotyped as associated with infectious disease, and the extent to which these experiences and health behaviors are affected by shifts in prejudices across the pandemic.

The short timeframe of the grant led to a focus on data gathering. In addition to a series of experiments to explore hypotheses related to threat detection, we created three nationally-representative longitudinal participant panels. Two of these were designed to assess (among other issues) prejudices against a variety of groups across time and the factors (COVID-related and otherwise) that might calibrate the temporal dynamics of those prejudices; the third panel was designed to capture the psychology of members of groups often targeted by prejudices.

One sub-project focused on how natural changes in disease avoidance motivation across the pandemic shaped thoughts about and behaviors toward ideological ingroup and outgroup members. Given that political party affiliation has been a strong predictor of COVID-related opinions, attitudes, and behaviors in the United States, we tested whether behavioral immune system responses (e.g., perceived infection threat, feelings of disgust, desires to avoid) were calibrated to political party affiliation as a cue to infection threat. Over and above powerful effects of in-party favoritism/out-party derogation based on participant political party affiliation, individuals dispositionally high in disease avoidance motivation showed greater BIS responses toward Republicans than toward Democrats. Importantly, within-person increases in disease avoidance motivation sensitive to the number of COVID-19 cases significantly predicted greater perceived infection threat by Republicans and less disgust toward and desire to avoid Democrats?even for Republican participants. These findings provide evidence for two important aspects of the behavioral immune system: (1) that it is able to acquire and track novel cues of threat and (2) that within-person changes in disease avoidance inclinations, sensitive to ecological levels of infectious disease threat, activate the suite of psychological tendencies designed to avoid infection?a process long presumed and now demonstrated for the first time.

In all, this multi-method research program is making significant theoretical contributions and will continue to do so. The gathered data will (1) provide insights into the temporal dynamics of responses to infectious disease threat, such as shifts in prejudices and policy preferences; (2) enable tests of the extent to which prejudiced and discriminatory reactions to a variety of groups (i.e., ethnic minorities, sexual minorities, the obese, the elderly, immigrants) are calibrated to infectious disease transmission over the course of outbreaks; (3) enable greater understanding of how the experiences and health-relevant decision making of groups who are stereotyped as associated with infectious disease are shaped by shifts in others? prejudices over the course of an outbreak; (4) lead to novel models of the time course and triggers of psychological and behavioral responses to infectious disease, thereby enhancing the effectiveness of efforts to deliver services and encourage transmission-limiting behavior during future epidemics; and (5) aid stakeholders in addressing the societal consequence of social phenomena triggered by infectious disease threat?such as prejudices?that may have broad implications that last long after a pandemic has ended.
